body:
Peter Pascual

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
Jump to navigation Jump to search
Saint Peter Pascual, by Francisco de Solís

Peter Pascual (c. 1227 – 1299/1300), in Latin originally Petrus Paschasius (Spanish: Pedro Pascual , Valencian : Pere Pasqual ), was a supposed Mozarabic theologian, bishop, and martyr. [1] His very existence has been called into question by recent scholarship. [2] [3]

Born in Valencia under the Almohads , he went to the University of Paris in 1238, shortly before Valencia fell to James I of Aragon . He may have held a canonry at the Cathedral of Saint Mary in Valencia before 1250, when he resigned it to join the Mercedarians at Rome. He later served James I as a tutor to his son Sancho , whom he also served as an assistant during the latter's archiepiscopate at Toledo . He became a wide-ranging preacher, delivering sermons in Tuscany and Andalusia , and writing tracts on various theological controversies. The authenticity of many works attributed to him is suspect, and it is possible that there were two writers of the same name. [1]

In 1296 he was appointed Bishop of Jaén , but was captured by the Kingdom of Granada and held captive for three years before being beheaded at Granada . [1] He is listed in the Roman Martyrology on October 23. [4]

References [ edit ]

  1. ^ a b c Robert Ignatius Burns, The Crusader Kingdom of Valencia: Reconstruction on a Thirteenth-Century Frontier (Cambridge, Massachusetts: Harvard University Press, 1967), p. 309.
  2. ^ Jaume Riera i Sans, "La invenció literària de sant Pere Pasqual" , Caplletra: Revista Internacional de Filologia , no. 1 (1986): 45–60.
  3. ^ Jocelyn N. Hillgarth, "Review of Dominicans, Muslims and Jews in the Medieval Crown of Aragon , The Catholic Historical Review , 96 , 4 (2010): 803.
  4. ^ [1]
